Pic by Tommy Gallagher.Reporter: Orlagh Mullan Nov Email: sport@derrypost  addthis, Steelstown manager Hugh McGrath has urged GAA supporters around the county to back his side in their Ulster Intermediate Championship quarter-final. googletag.cmd.push After beating Donegal’s Cloughaneely in a dramatic preliminary round game on Saturday, the Oacuteg’s will now face Monaghan champions Donaghmoyne in Celtic Park in a fortnight’s time. “Donaghmoyne are a good outfit. I’ve watched them twice now and they’ll not pass up as many chances as Cloughaneely,” said the Down man. “It’s great to have a home tie in Celtic Park and it would be greatwe could get as many people out to support us as possible – I think this group deserve that. “It’s been a long road since last year and losing the final so the more days that you can get with big support, the better. “We have never had that many supporters out and around our own county, it’s been very much our own group within the city, and it shows. “The group is tight, it will always be tight, and we stick together. The more we see of the city clubs sticking together, the better. “For years it was all about parish rivalries in the city but there’s no need for it. “We’re all competing on the same  and the sooner we help each other and get everybody up to the intermediate level to start off with, the better for football in the city.” McGrath’s men dominated the game, but in their first run at Ulster intermediate football the nerves were certainly there, and but for the crossbar in the dying seconds the Ballyarnett men could have exited the competition. Neil Forester tracks his man on Saturday afternoon. Pic by Tommy Gallagher. For the manager, the character on display was no surprise. “It wouldn’t be a Steelstown gamewe didn’t make it exciting for everyone in the stands. It’s a dficult one,” he said. “We were in uncharted territory here and we just had to see how the guys reacted. The positive thing that we got out of it was the result obviously. “The performance wasn’t what we wanted it to be, but I think when we went behind in the first half we showed our character again. “I don’t think that should ever be questioned with this group. They showed what they’re capable of doing. “Even when they go behind, they don’t panic – they just go through their process and make sure they get out on the right end of the scoreline. “We bossed the entire first half bar maybe three or four minutes of it, but Cloughaneely are not champions of Donegal and playing Division One football all year for no reason. A certain Derry manager warned me during the week that Cloughaneely were a very good outfit and they’d be very hard to beat. He’s never usually too far off the mark and he was exactly right. “There’s always going to be a sting from a team like that and they showed what they’re capable of. I think we showed what we’re capable of too. We’re capable of digging deep, we showed what our bench can do as well. “We’ve as many good players coming into the team as have started it and for us that’s a positive. “We need to build on it and take the next step. For us it was about getting a win in Ulster, next step is two wins in Ulster and we’ll see where we go from there.”  PREVIEW: Ulster a chance to throw off the shackles for Steelstown  The intermediate champions take on Cloughaneely in Letterkenny on Saturday. Pic by Catherine Comer.Reporter: Liam Tunney Nov Email: liam@derrypost  addthis, A disappointed Barney McGrellis broke from the post-match team huddle as the Creggan supporters surrounded their winning team behind them. googletag.cmd.push Having just been on the end of an agonising one-point defeat at the hands of the Antrim champions, there was an obvious feeling of dejection. “Im absolutely gutted,” McGrellis told the County Derry Post. “We did everything in our power today to come out on the right side, and the things we needed to fall our way didnt fall our way. “Fair play to Creggan, they are value for it, but there would be a few decisions Id feel aggrieved at. “Roseannas sending off was very soft, and possibly the Creggan red card as well, but the girls rallied. “The one thing we always ask them is to have no excuses.” Tasked with picking up the talented Eavanne Martin, McGrellis reserved praise for the midfielder Orla McEvoy, who took on the role with relish. “Orla is an unbelievable athlete and put everything into that today,” said McGrellis. Orla McEvoy was outstanding for her side on Saturday. Pic by Catherine Comer. “Every time weve asked her to pick up somebody, the other person has tended to be an afterthought. “We got our match ups right, we set up pretty well, but we lost a bit of shape in the second half and couldnt get enough ball into the forwards to do damage.” While most teams have to wait the guts of a year, Rossa are in the unique position of being able to put things right immediately. They travel to Mullaghbawn this weekend as the  Bridie McMenamin Shield competition begins, and manager McGrellis says the team has a chance to push on and improve. “Theres a lot hurt and pain there today, and normally when that happens you have a year to wait to put it right, whereas we have the opportunity to go out next week,” he said. “Were missing a few players next weekend but well go down to Mullaghbawn and do the same thing as we always do look for no excuses and try and put on our best performance “To get a chance to bounce back so quickly is nice. They are an unreal group, theyre so close and there are a lot of family connections. “The sky is the limit,they knuckle down they can go places. Success might look dferent now when they go up to intermediate, but there is no reason they cant continue to be successful.”  Heartbreak for Rossa as Creggan edge thrilling Ulster final  The Magherafelt side lost out by the slimmest of margins. Friday’s results in the other group threw up St Killians Garron Tower as the team they would facethey beat Knock. In the end it was a comfortable enough morning in Lavey for Maghera against Our Lady’s  St Patrick’s Knock with an early goal from Oisin McNicholl paving the way for a - to - win. McNicholl had opened the scoring within the first  seconds with a breakaway point and four minutes later Knock’s best player and free-taker Eoin Pucci fired over an equaliser. Then in the sixth minute Eoin Scullion played McNicholl in for the goal. The sliotar seemed to die on the heavy pitch and McNicholl scooped it home from close range. Maghera never looked back with Knock very dependent on Eoin Pucci frees to keep them in contact. The Maghera half-back line of Dara McGonigle, James Friel and Fionn McEldowney was in control throughout with Eoin Scullion dropping back from midfield as an extra shield. Scullion and Shea McKenna were on top at midfield and Peter McCullagh was always available to run at the knock defence. It was - to - at the water break with four of the Maghera points coming from McCullaghand that gap stretched to - to - by the interval with Jarlath McCollum eventually getting Knock’s first score from open play in the thminute. McCullagh hit two more frees and Callum O’Kane took a fine point when he took his player on in the thminute. Eoin Scullion and free-taker Pucci exchanged points on the re-start, and then Cormac Mullan’s goal in the thminute made sure that there would be no way back for Knock. The spade-work was done by McCullagh but Mullan still had plenty to do before he crashed the sliotar past Tiarnaacuten Davis. Davis brought off a good save from Shea O’Neill at the start of the last quarter that only produced three points, all of them top class scores. Knock could claim the score of the game when Shea Pucci fired over left-handed from right on the side-line. But that point was cancelled almost immediately by a fine long-range effort from Callum O’Kane and Fionn McEldowney fired over another fine point late in the game. Both semi-finalsare due to take place next week with the final scheduled for the weekend of December  . Armagh, who was the winner of the prestigious award last year. Good Luck!” Ulster GAA President Oliver Galligan said: “Volunteerism is at the heart of everything that happens in the GAA across the province and we are delighted that our initiative with Translink recognises the positive impact that our youth members have with their clubs and communities through a wide range of volunteer activities, including coaching, well-being schemes, fundraising and committee membership. “At the end of the GAA season, I would encourage all of our clubs to celebrate their own young leaders by entering a nomination for this award”. It’s a fairly cringeworthy experience watching so many people pretend to like each other and dance and act like they’re not in it for the next round. The reason I get so worked up about it is that I was watching musicians for years and years, before the Arts Council handed out cheques, just making great music. Some of them still do. Jeanette Hutton still does. I’ll end up sounding like a lick but it’s a small price to pay to get across her importance to music here. The easiest way to explain her is that she’s the real thing. An incredible vocalist that you’ve undoubtedly heardyou were ever out on a Saturday night in Derry. A gted songwriter that has changed yet again for her third record. An irreplaceable friend and all-round cool girl with the best taste in music you’re going to find. A genuinely fine human being.She once told me that hearing Let There Be Rock by AC DC on Tommy Vance’s rock show inspired her to pursue music and to join Philby, who toured with Mama’s Boys and played with Rory Gallagher. Philby gained a local following which got bigger and bigger and that eventually meant they could buy a transit van and move to London . But the dficulties of constant touring around a circuit that covered a lot of distance around England with little to no pay to, even worse, pay-to-play gigs caught up with them and the band parted ways. Not that this was a bad experience and the band had gained enough acclaim to get write ups in Kerrang magazine and gigs in the famous Marquee venue in London . After a year out back home, Jeanette got involved in a local jam session with Frankie Robinson and Mickey the Hat and that has developed into her becoming one of the most recognised and respected musicians in the town. This led to her band Lady J’S first album with husband Ruairi O’Doherty, bassist David Doherty and guitarist Marty McGill and produced the self-titled album and some of the best gigs the parish has seen. Like I said earlier, this lady, J, has the best taste in music you’ve ever heard, and she took an absolute swerve in her next project with her sister Noella. Blood, the album and the live experience was all things to all music fans, loud and acoustic, heavy, and sweet, lyrical, and melodic set against loud guitars, quiet guitars and familial vocal harmonies that can only be captured by relatives. The perfect storm and another chapter in the book of big Hutton. Now we’re at the next chapter, the one where it’s just Jeanette. “Melancholy Me” is described a collection of dark, reflective, and weighty tunes that showcases her as a more introspective writer with brooding stories to tell. I’ve always found her music to be like that, the delivery is ever changing in a way that a great musician seems to be able to do that without taking a wrinkle out of them but the over-arching substance that fills her songs is a constant. There are a lot of musician and listeners out there who have a lot to learn from Lady J Hutton. Keep up to date with all happenings Hutton on her Facebook page, Jeanette Hutton Music. She’ll also be supporting Damien Dempsey in the Millennium Forum on Saturday th January and tickets can be got for that herewww.millenniumforum shows damien-dempsey . Remember something, the best music is right on your doorstep, it isn’t on Facebook, it doesn’t matter about likes on social medial or Spoty numbers, you can’t listen to music on computer, and it will never feel as good as seeing a band live and you can do just thatyou follow this yellow brick roadhttps:nervecentre.ticketsolve shows . You’ll see me at Jeanette’s gig on Sunday in the Nerve Centre, where I should point out her Blood co-conspirator and actual blood relative, sister Noella Hutton will also be playing and feel free to title: Additional parking plan for Newcastle
story: A PLAN to develop a major extension to Donard Park car park in Newcastle has been approved by planners.Newry, Mourne and Down Council is investing pound, to formally develop a grass overspill area at the foothills of the Mournes to provide  new spaces.Local planners gave the scheme the green light at their monthly meeting last week, with the extended car park featuring  dedicated spaces for drivers with mobility issues.As part of the development proposal on land west of the existing car park, a six metre high ball stop fence is being erected and a . metre high paladin fence.There will also be a number of new footpaths, new lighting, landscaping and drainage.None of the statutory agencies have objected to the local authority proposal, but concern was expressed by one resident about the anti-social behaviour of young drivers using the car park.Recommending that the council proposal should be approved, planners said the current overspill car park is considered to be site a ldquosufficient distance from adjacent dwellings to prevent ldquoany unacceptable impacts.Planners say taking into account planning policy, consultee responses, planning history and responses, approval is recommended subject to a positive response from the Natural Environment Division which is currently outstanding.Planners have also stipulated that prior to any work starting, a final drainage assessment, including a detailed drainage network design and demonstration of how so-called out-of-sewer flooding will be addressed, must be agreed with them.No retained trees will be allowed to be felled or uprooted as part of the work to provide the new parking spaces.Planners have also warned that care will need to be taken during the construction phase to ensure there are no polluting discharges.Council chairwoman Cathy Mason and Mournes councillor Willie Clarke are both pleased that formal planning approval for the car park extension has been granted.Cllr Mason said she was delighted to see what she described as ldquosignicant investment in Newcastle to provide much-needed car parking for residents and visitors.ldquoThere has been considerable increase in so-called staycations and users of the outdoors and this investment will help alleviate the pressure on parking in the resort, she added.Cllr Clarke said the current overflow car park behind the football pitch at Donard Park was ldquounsightly and dficult to manage in wet weather.He continued: ldquoThe new car park will provide much-needed spaces at the foot of the Mournes.ldquoNewry, Mourne and Down Council is investing a signicant amount of money to replace the overspill park with a larger, more attractive one that will better serve the southern part of town that is seeing signicant regeneration and development.Cllr Clarke said the design of the new park took into account the need for improved environmentally friendly provisions such as electric car charging points, solar powered lighting and improved landscaping.He added: ldquoAlthough not required for planning, it is anticipated that improved picnic areas and potential for a sensory garden can also be incorporated at a later date. It is essential that we get security and management of car parking right at this popular location..prettyPhoto

title: Arkle and Collins’ make winning start as Downpatrick Pool League returns
story: FITZPATRICKrsquoS B............................COLLINSrsquo.........................................CONOR Vize gave Fitzpatrickrsquos a dream start when he overcame Chris Gordon in the opening game of the match.Adrian Galbraith levelled the scores after he defeated Bunter Cahill, before Chris Quinn shot Collinsrsquo into a lead they would never relinquish by beating Patrick Ferris.Chris Quinn gave himself another win, this time over Daren Fung, to make the score - before Ricky Hull pulled one back for Fitzpatrickrsquos with a victory over Chris Gordon.Andy Degean ensured it would be Collinsrsquo who came away with the points after he secured the win over Paul Craig.SAVAGErsquoS..........................................MIRABELLE A................................JOHNNY Craig kicked off proceedings with a win for his Mirabelle side over Reece McCormick before Jay Greavy squared up the scoreline with a victory over Shane McQuoid.Shay Blaney gave Savagersquos the lead after he defeated Pat McQuoid, but once again the scores went level whenThomas Curran overcame Declan Morgan.Savagersquos managed to pull out in front again, this time courtesy of William Duncanrsquos win over Dee Sharvin.However, the match settled with a fair share of the spoils after Stephen Sloan nabbed the win from Aaron McCarthyARKLE BAR....................................FITZPATRICKrsquoS A...........................DERMOT Feenan began his Arkle sidersquos four game win streak with a victory over Sean McCabe in the opening match-up.Gabriel Hogg defeated Mick Galbraith to extend the lead, before Tony Murray made it a hat-trick of wins with his win over Stefan McConvey.Arklersquos Dennis Feenan overcame James McGrath, before Fitzpatrickrsquos finally got off the mark as Mick Galbraith defeated Anthony Gilchrist.The result was already confirmed, but Fitzpatrickrsquos continued to battle and to his credit Stefan McConvey defeated James Keenan in the final game of the night.This weekrsquos fixtures: Mirabelle A v Fitzpatrickrsquos B, Savagersquos v Mirabelle B, Arkle v Round House.prettyPhoto

title: Ballynahinch put five past Antrim
story: BALLYNAHINCH men faced Antrim for the second time this season and ran out - winners in an excellent display of hockey at the weekend.The opening quarter started with a lsquoHinch pushback, with the ball being played around the back four and midfield.Matthew Martin passed back to Rea Coffey, who had some super runs up the right wing, before playing the ball round the back to Andrew Mulholland and Leslie Harrison.With both teams fighting hard for every ball, possession was going to play a key part in the game.Ashley Brown made a super pass up to Josh Higginson on the left wing, who had a brilliant cross into the Antrim circle that was just narrowly missed by Zak Patterson.With Antrim on the attack, they began pressing forward with lot of men. Antrim were able to break in the lsquoHinch circle several times only to be stopped by some brilliant defending by the back four.lsquoHinch were able to press up the pitch with some great put together passes from Craig Harkness to Jason Campbell and Scott Leetch, who were able to win a short corner.Ballynahinch were soon able to win another short corner after a deflection off an Antrim foot. Matthew Martin managed to slip the ball past the Antrim defence with a drag flick to give his side the lead.With Antrim looking to equalise the game, they began pressing hard and were rewarded with a short corner. The shot was saved by Martin, who was able to play the ball out of the circle, to end the first quarter.As the second quarter commenced, the lsquoHinch men began committing men forward on the attack that included a superb pass from Scott Leetch up to Jason Campbell, only to be denied with a great save from the Antrim lsquokeeper.Antrimrsquos forward broke in to the lsquoHinch circle, although he was met by lsquokeeper Aaron Donnell who saved the shot smartly.Andrew Mulholland had some long runs, beating Antrim defenders in the process, before passing the ball to Jason Campbell, who slipped the ball to Craig Harkness on the flick, scoring Hinchrsquos second goal of the day.Antrim were not going to give up easily, although came under more pressure when Ashley Brown threw an aerial to Jason Campbell, who was stopped in his tracks by the opposing defender.The third quarter began with Adam Dodds tackling the Antrim midfield before crossing the ball to Jason Campbell to get on the score sheet taking it to -.However, Antrim were determined to keep lsquoHinch from extending their lead even further with some great tackles and team play.Both teams were able to create chances but neither could convert until lsquoHinchrsquos resilience paid off once more.Scott Leetchrsquos pass up to Lewis Higginson allowed him to hit the ball to the back post for Andrew McIlwaine to tap in.The final quarter included end to end play from both teams for the first few minutes, but once they had settled back in to the game, lsquoHinch started to build.The play continued with Ashley Brown throwing an aerial up the pitch, that was brought down safely by Matthew Martin to score his second goal of the match. This quarter continued with Hinch applying pressure in the Antrim  and trying to increase the score.However, the scoring was completed in what was a one sided affair.Well done to Aaron Donnell and his defence on their first clean sheet of the season.Ballynahinch extend their thanks to all their supporters and to the umpires, as well as the Primrose Ballynahinch for their continued sponsorship.The player of the match was Ashley Brown..prettyPhoto

title: Chance to send letters to Santa in Glasswater Wood
story: EAGER children are visiting Glasswater Wood just outside Crossgar to post their Christmas letters to Santa Claus.A new Santa Claus post box in the woods has become a destination for local families enjoying a country walk as their childrenrsquos excitement builds for the big day ndash with a promise that all letters will go to Lapland.Itrsquos the brainchild of local grandfather-of-four Michael McClements, who created the post box to entertain and please local children.Michael, who runs McClements Construction of Crossgar, said he created the post box out of gas cylinders with help from several local businesses.Itrsquos his latest kind and generous gesture following his creation of wooden houses which he has put on ious trees which tell the stories of the Gruffalo, The Three Little Pigs and other popular childrenrsquos stories.Micheal explained: ldquoI began to make the little houses for the entertainment of my grandchildren as something to do during the last lockdown and thought I would put them on the trees at Glasswater Wood. For many local families, getting out for a walk with the children was the only activity they could do at that time.ldquoMy grandchildren really enjoyed seeing the little houses in the woods and they encouraged me to make more. I thought the Santa Claus post box would be good too and Irsquom glad to say that dozens of little children are already posting their letters into the box since it went up last week.Michael used old gas cylinders to make the Santa Claus head and body and a steel funnel for the hat.He was helped by John Killen, of Abbeyview Engineering, who welded the pieces together, Kenny Martin, who shotblasted and painted it, and Philip Houston, of Get Noticed Signs, who did all the signs for the post box and the cartoon graphics for the boxes.Michael said: ldquoI have to thank everyone who helped me out and give of their time and work freely all in aid to help the children enjoy the woods and the run-up to Christmas.ldquoWhen Irsquom walking my grandchildren, they run from box to box and they love to see the fairy tales and I get as much out of it when I see other little children running along as well.ldquoIrsquom told by some other parents and grandparents that it used to be hard to get their children out for a walk and now they are being asked to go for a walk all the time. Irsquom delighted that all the children are enjoying this..prettyPhoto

title: Children hope to deliver net carbon emissions
story: LOCAL schools have joined forces with Newry, Mourne and Down Council and made a pledge to help tackle climate change.Council chairwoman Cathy Mason was delighted to welcome a delegation of pupils from schools across the district to council offices in Downpatrick this week.The pupils presented her with their lsquoLeaf Pledgesrsquo on climate change in the hope that the Council will work together with them in the fight to deliver net zero carbon emissions by .The Eco-Group at Down High School are passionate about encouraging young to have a voice in creating a greener future in our local community.Inspired by the recent COP conference in Glasgow, which brought world leaders together to help accelerate action towards climate change targets, the pupils developed the lsquoLeaf Pledge Projectrsquo.This was an initiative originally started by the World Wildle Foundation , in which young people share their personal pledge to the planet.The aim is to send a message to world leaders that young people are ready to fight against climate change and they need them to step up and do their bit to protect our future.Down High school adapted the WWF leaf pledge idea to include the pledges they would like their local council, instead of world leaders, to make, regarding climate change.This project was promoted across all schools in the Council area, with a huge number of schools becoming actively involved.The schools used the initiative to educate pupils on the climate crisis during the COP summit fortnight.Rachel Wilson, a teacher at Down High School, said: ldquoThis project has given pupils a  to voice their concerns about climate change.It has also demonstrated how working together collaboratively across the district can result in positive outcomes for everyone.Cllr Mason said: ldquoI am excited to receive these climate lsquoLeaf Pledgesrsquo from our young people here today.She said the council recognised climate change as a ldquoserious threat to our way of le and has declared a climate emergency.She continued: ldquoWe are currently working across departments to develop a Climate Adaptation Plan to provide resilience to the impacts of climate change including flooding, droughts, storms, and sea level rise.ldquoWe are also working in partnership with other organisations and the local community to reduce our carbon footprint and our impact on the environment.ldquoListening to the voice of our youth is incredibly important, as climate change will impact the future generations of our community..prettyPhoto

title: East Down runners at Forest Park
story: TOLLYMORE Forest Park was the venue for a multi distance event at the weekend, organised by  Extreme.While the scenery is an obvious attraction to the runners, they come in the knowledge that that they will face several hills and off road terrain, so it is not a race for those who like to chase times and personal bests.As per previous years, there was a K, a half marathon, a full marathon and an ultra marathon all on offer with East Down AC represented in both the K and the full marathon .With four races and routes it could have been confusing but for those doing the half marathondistance, it was a one loop course which the marathonersthen did twice.For those doing the ultra marathon it was a case of back round for a third time. The races also had dfering start times with the longer distances starting earlier in the day.Doing laps often keeps the runners compact in terms of marshalling and spectating but it can mean that those doing the longer distances are tested mentally when they see others finishing.It is sometimes hard to carry on for the next loop when you can see others reaching the end of their efforts. It also means where there is a hill or a tricky part of the race, you will see it more than onceyou are doing the marathon or the ultra. The k route was slightly separate but also included a few steep sections so it was not an easy option by any means.Marguerite Robinson had been training hard to regain fitness after a layoff with injury and had hoped to be ready to use her half marathon slot, which was a deferred entry from last yearrsquos event, that was called off due to Covid- restrictions.However, as race day approached, she realised that on this occasion that she might be taking on more than she could chew and certainly more than she would enjoy so she wisely switched to the K.She was easy with her decision once the race got underway and even more so during the last mile when she was running the drag uphill from the gate to the finish. She completed in . and was th female .Declan Teague has been in fine marathon form recently, packing in three such races in short succession from September into October, but this one was notable as it got him to number  in his tally.Unfortunately since his last race, he has had to reduce his training miles due to niggles and he arrived at the start line knowing that he was going to have to dig deep to get round.He was therefore delighted to hook up with Phillip Vint as the race got underway and said that the camaraderie took their mind off the big climbs and got them through the first hour with ease.Phillip was on his way to his th marathon and in his usual understated fashion he was just there to get on with it.The commitment and consistency of these guys has to be admired.As much as Declan was enjoying the company, he urged Phillip to press on to pursue his own pace. Phillip very gradually eased away over the miles ahead and finished a superb th overall in three hours and  minutes.This would be a commendable time on tarmac let alone on an off road event. Declan stuck to his own rhythm and was happy with his time of . which placed him nd out of the  who completed.Clare Carson was also in for the marathon distance and taking it in her stride she dipped in just under the five hours to add another one to the long list that she is accumulating.They all commented that they found the downhills as tough as the ups and the quad muscles had definitely taken a battering, but despite the testing route, it is one they will likely repeat.Stephen Heasley, who was in Tollymore to take part in the ultra distance, reported back that he was a lsquoDNFrsquo. For those of you who are unsure what DNF means, it is short for lsquodid not finishrsquo.Most would assume that this would be a major disappointment.In Stephenrsquos case though, perhaps it would be more accurate to say that he had a change of plan rather than a failure.Although he was finding it tough going, he waited until the end of lap two to call it a day so in fact he completed a marathon while considering his options.For many of us managing to finish a marathon on a good day would be a challenge. To do so on a ldquobad day seems almost a triumph.It was certainly the right decision for Stephen on the day and hopefully he will now take time for recovery before his next escapade.Jonny Holmes had taken part in the NIMAA XC Championships a month ago as a way of trying his hand at cross country running.That event also stood as selection for the NI team for the North South Challenge. Based on the results that day, the Masters Association drew up teams of six plus one reserve for each age group -, -, - and so on.Jonny was duly notied that he was picked to run as reserve in the - category and so he turned up at Queens Playing Fields last Saturday, slightly concerned as to how he would cope given the standard of the runners.He had no need to worry as he paced it well and did himself and the club proud.He was rd in the end and completed the five lap muddy circuit in  odd minutes. He expressed his awe of the standard at the front of the race and felt that it was great to have the experience of being part of such a competitive event.This weekend sees the cross country season continue with a large EDAC squad heading to Comber for the Comber Cup and some juniors travelling to Santry in Dublin for the All-Ireland Even Age Group Championships as part of the Co Down team. Good luck to all concerned..prettyPhoto

title: Ex First Minister says religion important part of political life
story: FORMER First Minister Arlene Foster has told an audience in Downpatrick she gets annoyed when people say religion should be taken out of politics.Mrs Foster, who is a member of the Church of Ireland, said having a strong Christian faith should have a positive impact on politics.In one of her first public appearances since she quit politics, Mrs Foster was interviewed by former UTV presenter Gerry Kelly in the Saint Patrick Centre last Thursday evening.In front of a live audience, she opened up about her faith journey, her political career and the trauma of the Troubles.ldquoChristianity doesnrsquot call you to be neutral. It calls you to be salt and light about what you believe in, she said.ldquoIt does annoy me when people say you have to take religion out of politics and leave it at the doorhelliplike it only happens at the weekend. It is part of who you are.ldquoYour Christianity and your faith is something that is with you all the time. You canrsquot just leave it at home on Sunday night and go out without it on Monday.Mrs Foster said she does not hold grudges against those who had hurt her, including former colleague Edwin Poots, who ousted her from the DUP leadership in May before being forced out of office himself just weeks later.Reflecting on the decision by Sinn Fein to collapse the executive with the resignation of then Deputy First Minister Martin McGuinness in , she said: ldquoWe got into a spiral and we couldnrsquot stop it and it got to a point then where the assembly collapsed and of course I regret that it was down for three years.She said she liked the late DUP leader Ian Paisley very much. ldquoHe used to joke with me and say, lsquoHow are the Anglicans doing Arlenersquo Asked by Mr Kellyshe thought Dr Paisley had mellowed over the years, she said: ldquoI never knew Dr Paisley personally until   and I think he probably was in a dferent space than he had been in the Sixties, Seventies and Eighties.She declined to speculate on what might have changed him. ldquoI donrsquot know. I canrsquot answer that. I only know he was very supportive of me as a female and an Anglican and as an outsider. He asked me to be in the administration in  which I have always been very thankful for.Mrs Foster said her Christian faith helped her to seek common ground with people she did not agree with, adding that her reason forgoing into government with Sinn Fein was to make sure that her children and others did not endure what she went through as a child.This included the attempted murder in  on her father, John, an RUC reservist, living on the Fermanagh border, and a bomb attack on her school bus driver in which her friend was left severely injured.Recalling the gun attack on her father, when she was around eight years old, she said he came crawling back from the barn, after gunshots were fired, with blood dripping from his forehead.ldquoIt was a very strange time, she said. ldquoMy mother was sitting at the kitchen table and I donrsquot know what she was doing but I will never forget her face. She just froze.Ms Foster said it was not politically correct to say it, but she felt she benefited from being educated at an all-girl school, where she grew in confidence.The former political leader said she was enjoying her new role in journalism as a presenter on GB news - but said more must be done to tackle the hurtful abuse on social media particularly against women.Mrs Foster was welcomed by Dr Tim Campbell, director of the St Patrick Centre, who said her personal story was incredibly interesting.He remarked: ldquoArlene Foster was extremely gracious and gave very generously of her time and people in the audience responded to her warmth..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C  November 21%2C 2001
story: NEWCASTLE mdash An appeal has been made by members of a Newcastle pressure group for more community support to help in the fight to keep the Rock Pool open.The Friends of the Rock Pool group, which formed in January following the news that Down Council was considering closing the  year-old facility because of rising overheads and ain visitor numbers, held a special meeting on Wednesday night.The event was convened because just a handful of supporters attended the action grouprsquos last meeting in September.As a result of this low turnout, letters were sent to members telling them the previous meeting had been ldquovery poorly attended and the survival of the Rock Pool ldquowould not succeed on the efforts of three or four people.Speaking during the meeting, the grouprsquos chairwoman, Mary Hull, said the Friends of the Rock Pool would only continue to existmembers ldquoworked together as a group.ldquoThe core we had at the start has sadly fallen away and we need to regroup. Unless we have the backing of the public, Down Council could turn around and say they donrsquot think they should back us and this is why we are calling for additional numbers.BALLYNAHINCH mdash A senior police officer has this week appealed for an end of sectarian violence in Ballynahinch.The plea by Inspector Paul McClean come after Nationalists and Loyalists again clashed this weekend in a series of running battles in the market town.Trouble flared at The Square late on Friday night and continued into the early hours of Saturday, with police officers being pelted with stones and fireworks.Violence erupted after Nationalists were blamed for smashing the window of a pub used by Loyalists and at one point up to  people spilled out on to the streets and became embroiled in a number of fights.No one was seriously injured, but people attending aat the White Horse Hotel had to remain in the premises until am for police to clear the area.Additional police were deployed to help restore calm and appealing for an end to he trouble Inspector McClean urges people on both sides not to escalate the situation in the town.DOWNPATRICK mdash Downpatrick is in line for another major housing development. Planning officials have this week approved the construction of  new houses.The homes, which are to be built at the disused quarry of Racecourse Hill, will be developed in tandem with  new car parking spaces.Details of the scheme, which is being proposed by the Downpatrick firm of OrsquoBoylersquos, were made public at Monday nightrsquos meeting of Down Council.News of the scheme has been welcomed by councillor Ann Trainor who believes the quarry will be transformed as a result of the ambitious scheme.Mrs Trainor said the quarry has become something of an eyesore over recent yeas and believes the new housing scheme will further enhance the regeneration of this key area in the town.She said that over the past number of years the nearby Flying Horse and Model Farm housing estates have been transformed and is confident the quarry area at the Racecourse Hill is also set for a new lease of le.ARDGLASS ndash Armed robbers made off with several hundred pounds from a fish processing factory in Ardglass on Friday morning.At around . am two men, one armed with a sawn-off shotgun, burst into the office at Milliganrsquos factory at the harbour and ordered staff to lie on the floor.The men then took the cash float, which police have confirmed was several hundred pounds, before making off in a silver coloured vehicle.The gunman has been described as around  or  years of age, approximately rsquorsquorsquo tall, with a round face and of medium build. He was dressed in a white hooded boiler suit and was wearing trainers and possibly a woollen hat.The second robber was about rsquorsquorsquo tall, of a slim or medium build and with short dark hair. Both men, who had Belfast accents, sped of in the silver vehicle, which was later found abandoned in the Meadow Court area of Ardglass. It has been reported stolen from Killyleagh.CASTLEWELLAN ndash A senior Sinn Fein politician has called for those responsible for the weekend attack on the Castlewellan republican memorial to stop ldquocausing heartache for the families of the IRA dead.Assembly man Mick Murphyrsquos comments came this week after the controversial Lower Square memorial was vandalised late on Friday night or in the early hours of Saturday.The Celtic cross which dominated the memorial, was severely damaged and hda to be removed leaving only the plinth on which the names of the dad republicans are etched.The memorial to commemorate ten IRA members killed during the Troubles was officially unveiled on Sunday, September .Mr Murphy called on those responsible for the attack to come forward so he can ask them why this was done as he believes ldquothere has been enough suffering in both communities.The Assemblyman added: ldquoWhile this monument may not have been everyonersquos cup of tea, the reality is that it was a monument to people who died in pursuit of freedom in Ireland, he said.SAINTFIELD ndash Subtle changes which have helped transform a number of businesses in the heart of Saintfieldrsquos conservation area were detailed during a special briefing session in the town last week.Representatives from the business community joined property owners and members of Saintfield Town Committee for a progress report on the continuing work to regenerate a number of key buildings.The work forms part of an ambitious townscape heritage initiative which is currently underway in the market town along with other similar schemes in Downpatrick and Killough.The White Horse Inn, one of the oldest buildings in Saintfield and which itself has featured heavily in the heritage initiative, was the setting for the progress report delivered by Mrs Harriet Devlin.The Saintfield Town Committee official, who is heavily involved in the project, paid tribute to the ious business and home owners who played key roles in helping to regenerate their respective premises.She said the work has transformed the conservation area and said while not all the schemes involved major building work, they did succeed in raising the profile of the historic town.KILLYLEAGH ndash Killyleagh Community Playgroup has been wrongly praised by Department of Education inspectors.In a recently published report the inspectors praised the happy, family atmosphere and found the relationships between staff and children were very good.The inspectors said the staff provide the children with high levels of support and reassurance which help the children grow in confidence and independence.Accommodation at the playgroup, which is based at the Bridge Centre, is good and staff make effective use of available space.ldquoThe staff are hardworking: their commitment is evident in the daily preparation of an attractive learning environment which is set out into distinct areas of play and is enhanced by displays of the childrenrsquos work, photographs and books, said the report.KILLOUGH ndash A grain store in Killough is to be converted into a new dwelling.The scheme, which borders Main Street and Palatine Square, is being proposed by the villagersquos Palatine Trust.It has been given the green light by local planners who have been told the move involves the redevelopment of part of an existing stable block.DUNDRUM ndash A new holiday cottage is to be constructed in Dundrum.Planning officials have this week approved the development which will include the demolition of a number of existing buildings at Castle Hill.Following the demolition, the rubble is to be reused in the construction of the new holiday cottage, which in addition to stone walls will also feature a slated roof..prettyPhoto

title: Hoops advance to Dalzell Cup final
story: CELTIC Bhoys marched into the final of the Bobby Dalzell Cup with a comprehensive victory over local rivals Killough at a windswept Ballyhornan on Friday night.Two goals in each half, including a brace from Celtic striker Jay Gibney, was enough to ensure it would be the Hoops who would be contending for this yearrsquos title on December .To both teams credit, the number of supporters that flooded through the gates to watch this spectacle was more than commendable, with hundreds of people in attendance to witness what is historically a feisty encounter between the sides mdash this occasion being no dferent.Killough, donning their new kit, kicked off, but in a matter of moments found themselves defending a free-kick in a dangerous area, although Celtic centre back Gary Carberry saw his effort well saved by lsquokeeper Christopher Mallon.The opening minutes played out to a rapid pace of football, with the wind unsure of which direction to blow resulting in both teams attempting to play on the ground.Killoughrsquos first big opportunity came courtesy of a Connor Kelly free-kick after team-mate Cillian Burns was pulled down by defender Blaine Connolly unfairly.However, Kellyrsquos effort just whisked over the crossbar in what would prove to be a seldom chance for the village side in the opening  minutes.What Celtic seemed to have in their arsenal which Killough lacked was showing clinical precision and accuracy from their set pieces.With seven minutes on the clock, the Hoops would have their first of  corners throughout the match, with the Killough defence failing to clear the danger with any conviction, allowing the ball to float back across the box and into the path of Celtic marksman Jay Gibney.The striker made no mistake with the finish and the deadlock was broken.Referee James McCreesh certainly had his work cut out, as he consistently gave verbal warnings to both teams and their management as he did a commendable job controlling the pace of the contest.However, his patience was tested one too many times and after a quarter of an hour, Killoughrsquos Kevin Groves received the first yellow card of the game for a tackle on Gerard Collins.Celticrsquos Peter Casey struck the resultant free and was unlucky to see his effort kiss the top of the crossbar.The Hoops continued their pressure and were rewarded with a corner. Barry Treacy, whose set piece efforts were fantastic throughout the  minutes, stepped up to strike a low cross into the box for captain Mikey Rice to tap in and double his sidersquos lead.Rice was instrumental for Celtic and deservedly was awarded man of the match for his efforts.A manic couple of minutes ensued after another corner caused Killough problems, the ball this time falling to Casey who saw his left-footed effort crash off the underside of the crossbar and somehow away to safety.Celtic kept their relentless efforts in attack and a moment later they thought they had their third, but their strike was ruled out for offside. Killough then failed to properly dispatch the ball up the pitch, allowing Hoopsrsquo striker Jordan McCoubrey to attack their goal.However, McCoubrey was left frustrated when his appeal for a penalty was waved off by McCreesh.Killoughrsquos Declan Burns received a booking for a hearty tackle on the opposition before team-mate and lsquokeeper Mallon managed to ert the ball away from the net in a dramatic goal line scramble.In what was an admittedly underwhelming performance by Killough, custodian Mallon made a number of inspiring saves throughout the match and kept the final score at a much more respectable tally.Celticrsquos Casey must have thought he had been the subject of a curse, after his third long ranged effort in the space of  minutes struck the woodwork, this time a spectacular  yard effort thumping against the upper left.Killough managed to weather the storm and their best chance of the half came from captain Gareth Georgersquos free-kick which sailed wide of the post before Celticrsquos Connolly picked up a yellow card for a combination of fouls.That signalled the last signicant action of the opening  as Celtic led by two at the half-time interval.Upon the restart, Shaun Megahey managed to sneak past the Killough backline to force a point blank range save from Mallon as changes were made to both sides, including the introduction of Stephen Galbraith for the Hoops.Carberry was the latest entry into the book after dragging down Killoughrsquos Kelly before the village side suffered an injury blow in the form of midfielder Matt McKiernan on the hour mark.The game had settled down at this point, with Killough still deciding whether to stick or twist as they knew they needed a goal, but one wrong move and the game would be put beyond their reach.Mallon continued to impress in goals, with an eye-catching one handed save off a Carberry header, although at the th minute the result was put beyond doubt.A calamity of errors in the Killough defence allowed Gibney to square the ball to substitute Galbraith, who tapped into the open net to completely crush their opponentsrsquo fighting spirit.Killough are known for their resilience and kept fighting to the conclusion, but it was clear that it wouldnrsquot be their day as the clock wound down.Megahey picked up a yellow for the Hoops before his opponents saw a penalty appeal for a hand ball shut down.Tempers continued to flair as Killoughrsquos Ruairi Sharvin added his name to the list of yellow card recipients just before his sidersquos misery compounded when Gibney added Celticrsquos fourth of the match with a neatly struck finish.Killough resorted to shooting from distance but werenrsquot having much luck, with Jack McLoughlinrsquos effort the only to really cause Celtic custodian Nathan Curran to spring into action with a confident one handed save.Groves did manage to loop a headed effort past Curran. However, as per the theme of the match, Celticrsquos defence managed to clear the ball before it could cross the line.McCreesh blew his whistle for the final time to send the Celtic fans into raptures as the players audibly voiced their pleasure at making yet another final.Man of the match and Hoopsrsquo skipper Mikey Rice gave his thoughts on the performance after the contest.ldquoEveryone knows what theyrsquore getting with Celtic Bhoys and Killough, big hits, hard tackles and a great spectacle for the neutral, he said.ldquoYou see the amount of people who came down here, especially for the Newcastle league teams, itrsquos brilliant. It was always going to be a great game and I respect Killough a lot, he continued.ldquoI think there was a few people here watching the match who will be featuring in next weekrsquos semi-final between Dundrum and Ardglass, so hopefully we gave them a wee bit of fear to face us.Celtic Bhoys: N Curran S Megahey, B Connolly, G Carberry M Rice , G Collins, B Treacy, P Casey, J Gibney, J McCoubrey, N Williams-McCabe.Subs: C Kerr, S Galbraith, S McMahon, C McCartan.Killough: C Mallon, S Og Burns, G George , E Gargan, R Sharvin, M McKiernan, D Burns, K Groves, C Burns, C Kelly, J McLoughlin.Subs: D Looney, T McIlhone, L Murphy, R Burns, D Taggart.Yellow cards: K Groves, D Burns, R Sharvin.Corners: Celtic Bhoys , Killough .Offsides: Celtic Bhoys , Killough ..prettyPhoto

title: Launch of blog to help needs of BAME residents in district
story: A NEW blog site for Newry, Mourne and Down Intercultural Forum has been launched.The forum was established in  to develop a strategic approach to identy the needs of black, Asian and minority ethnicgroups living in the district.Launched last week at South Eastern Regional Collegersquos Newcastle campus, the blog site provides a  in which each of the partners working together can share vital information to create an inclusive community that embraces ersity.Council chairwoman Cathy Mason said: ldquoOn behalf of the council and the PEACE IV team, I would like to thank Forsythe Consulting for the effective facilitation of the Forum and RANE Digital Marketing and Kernaghan Consulting for their work on the creation of this online blog.ldquoIt will act as a vital tool in educating, advising, and engaging with the community on the important work undertaken by the forum and the interagency partners involved.The forum seeks to maximise resources and opportunities to promote equity, ersity and interdependence so that citizens with a BAME background feel recognised, fairly treated, safe and valued in the community.It is made up of representatives from the,Southern Health and Social Care Trust, The Ethnic Minority Centre, Police Service of Northern Ireland, Advice Newry Mourne and Down, Wah Help Chinese Community Association, South Eastern Regional College, Southern Regional College, Newry Chamber of Commerce, County Down Rural Community Network and the Northern Ireland Housing Executive.The project is supported by the European Unionrsquos PEACE IV Programme which is managed by the Special EU Programmes Body . Match funding has also been provided by The Executive Office in Northern Ireland and the Department for Rural and Community Development in Ireland.Anyone who would like to participate on the forum, or would like more information, should contact the forum by email nmdorum@gmail or through the blog at www.nmd.org blog..prettyPhoto

title: Lidl’s £32m Newcastle store gets green light
story: PLANS for a new pound.m Lidl store in Newcastle have been given the green light.Formal planning approval for the new store came at last weekrsquos meeting of Newry, Mourne and Down Councilrsquos Planning Committee.The development proposal mdash which includes a dedicated new base for the Mourne Mountain Rescue Team mdash relates to the former St Maryrsquos Girlsrsquo Primary School site in the resort.Outline approval for the supermarket was initially granted for the multi-million pound development in October last year, with the formal approval granted last week featuring a new entrance off the Bryansford Road.As part of the development proposal, Lidl intends to demolish the former primary school to pave the way for the new , square metre store and provide  parking spaces in tandem with a landscaping proposal.The proposed new  square metre base for the mountain rescue team, which is expected to cost in the region of pound, to build, has parking provision for eight vehicles, alongside four disabled spaces and an additional four reserved for parents and toddlers.Plans to redevelop the former primary school site were originally submitted in January  to replace Lidlrsquos existing base at Railway Street in the resort.And while permission for the store was initially granted, it was subsequently quashed as the result of a procedural error in relation to the papers submitted to the local authorityrsquos Planning Committee.A new pedestrian crossing at the Bryansford Road junction with Shimna Road forms part of the proposal.Lidl argued that its current base at Railway Street in Newcastle is too small to allow the store to carry the companyrsquos full range of goods, highlighting issues with narrow aisles and inadequate parking provision.Lidl said the Railway Street base was only supposed to be a temporary home until a larger unit could be found, with Lidl insisting that it has been looking for an alternative town centre site for over decade without success until the former primary school site became available.A number of objections were lodged with planners, including that the development was not in keeping with the residential nature of the area and that the closure of the retailerrsquos existing store would have a detrimental impact on Newcastle town centre and surrounding inconvenience stores.Concern was also expressed about the proposed storersquos impact on traffic and the potential for increased flooding.During last weekrsquos Planning Committee meeting it was confirmed that in order to comply with the recommended planning approval, developers must adhere to  conditions ying from the use of floodlights on-site to a final drainage assessment.However, concerns were raised by a private company Don Holdings Ltd mdash which has planning approval for the construction of a neighbouring apartment block mdash over the ldquolawfulness of the new supermarket proposal.They claimed Lidl Northern Ireland had not provided a sufficient detailed site plan and called on the local authority to investigate the claims.In addition, the company raised concerns over the access route into the site, which they claim causes ldquoroad safety issues.In an objection letter to the planning committee, solicitors on behalf of Don Holding Ltd said: ldquoIt is important to note that our client does not object to the concept of a Lidl store and Mountain Rescue Centre on this site, however, the current application is fundamentally flawed.ldquoWe have serious concerns that members [councillors] are being asked to make a decision based on inaccurate information, which is especially concerning when it leads to signicant public safety issues.However, council officers said that the objectors failed to identy a planning policy that showed why the council had made the wrong decision in recommending the application for approval.A council planning officer told last weekrsquos meeting that there was nothing in planning policy or legislation that says that ldquoyou should refuse an applicationthe applicant cannot demonstrate ownership of land.The officer continued: ldquoThe objectors havenrsquot referred to any policy or legislation and planning applications get approved all the time in circumstances that applicants donrsquot own land.ldquoItrsquos up to the applicant before they commence development, to have the necessary title before they continue with that development. This case is no dferent to any other application that would cause members to refuse this application.At the conclusion of the planning meeting, councillors unanimously backed the plannersrsquo approval recommendation on a proposal by Mournes councillor Glyn Hanna which was seconded by Crotlieve councillor Gerry OrsquoHare..prettyPhoto

title: Lift off for Newcastle ferris wheel
story: NEWCASTLE is set to get its first ever ferris wheel mdash but it wonrsquot be a permanent fixture.The wheel will be located at Castle Park in the heart of the resort next summer for three months after the green light was given by Newry, Mourne and Down Council planners.The -mete high wheel mdash which will provide spectacular views of the Mournes, Dundrum Bay and across the resort mdash will be in place every June, July and August until .Planners gave the green light for the towering new wheel at last weekrsquos monthly meeting of the local authorityrsquos Planning Committee.At the end of August each year, the wheel will be removed, with confirmation that planning permission for Newcastlersquos latest tourist attraction has been granted welcomed by local politicians.South Down MLA Colin McGrath revealed he was involved with the funfair promoters from the outset and is pleased that the big wheel application has been approved.He added: ldquoNewcastle has so much to offer visitors and the wider Mournes is growing in popularity with such a iety of activities for the young and not so young. I believe this ferris wheel will be a further pull for people to visit Newcastle.ldquoI want to thank local planners who worked alongside council officers and the applicant to get the proposal over the line.Mournes councillor, Laura Devlin said the new attraction will be a ldquomajor boost for tourism in Newcastle.Councillors were told last week that the wheelrsquos location had to comply with the districtrsquos development plan.In addition, it was confirmed that no objections were received from any of the statutory agencies including the Rivers Agency, Department for Infrastructurersquos Historic Environment, the Environment Agency and the local authorityrsquos environmental health department.The temporary approval for the ferris wheel expires at the end of August ..prettyPhoto

title: Portaferry camogs claim senior title
story: THE final whistle in Drumaness on Sunday brought untold relief for the players of Portaferry and their supporters who have waited so long for this particular day.It triggered celebrations that have until now been the preserve of the hurlers and I have no doubt that there were plenty of sore heads on Monday morning.Indeed it would not surprisethose celebrations continue for a while as their next outing is against Tyrone champions Eglish in the Ulster Championship on the last weekend of January.The fact that Portaferry only took the lead for the first time five minutes from the final whistle only added to the drama of a final that will not live long as a spectacle.There was too much at stake for both teams and they both set up defensively to keep scores to a minimum.It had worked for Portaferry in the two games leading into the final when they scored comfortable wins over both last yearrsquos finalists, Clonduff and Ballygalget.The concession of just - and - in those games was enough to allow Niamh Mallon to keep the score-board running at the other end.Liatroim had been a little more open in their previous two games mdash a defeat to Ballygalget and then a semi-final win over Ballycran mdash but Dearbhla Magee had been majestic in the middle of the pitch.Dearbhla Coleman moved out to double-mark Magee, the rest of the defence closed down the space and Portaferry again were hard to break down.At the other end, the Fontenoys employed Deirdre McCabe to stick like glue to Mallon, while Natalie McKibbon stepped in as sweeper.The Fontenoys probably conceded more frees than they would have liked, but the Ports were tense and they were not punished all the time.Eventually Liatroim got going at the other end and started to put it up to Portaferry, going four points ahead inside the opening quarter, all four points driven over from frees by Dearbhla Magee.Karen McMullan, Deirdre McCabe and Kate McAleenan were all on top at the back, but eventually Niamh Mallon opened her account taking a pass from Cliodhna Coleman on  minutes to boost her sidersquos morale with a fine point before the delayed water-break.She added two more points from frees before the first goal chance was created by Liatroim right on half-time.However, Aimee McAleenanrsquos shot was smothered by Fiona McGarry, although McAleenan recovered to pop over a point to see the teams change ends at - to -.Portaferry now had the breeze behind them but they struggled to bring accuracy to their shooting. Mallon eventually pointed in the th minute only for Alana McCrickard to take a pass from Dearbhla Magee and fire over a minute later.Mallon responded with a huge score from play and then a th minute point to level the tie at - eachHowever, Dearbhla Magee gave her side the lead once more with a free after a clever move between Aimee McAleenan and Karen McMullan.But Mallon eventually levelled the tie again with a huge free from  metres in the nd minute and then five minutes from time stepped over a free in the left corner where the m line meets the side-line.It was the toughest angle she had faced, but she scored the point and Portaferry held on for a famous first title.Mallon was the player of the match. Portaferry would not have won without her contribution, having scored all eight points, but they also would not have won without the defensive wall they put in front of Fiona McGarry.Mary Jo Mageean, Dearbhla Coleman and Saoirse Sands smothered everything that the Fontenoys threw at them. But on a day like this, everyone put their shoulder to the wheel and it was enough to break the dam.ldquoIt is very hard to win the first. We have tried very hard over the past few years to win this title and it feels so good to actually get there, said Portaferry team mentor Martin Mallon, who was feeling the relief after the final whistle.ldquoI wonrsquot tell you a lie. We were very anxious coming into this final, all of us. You could see it in our play.Girls were tense and nervous out there and Liatroim took advantage.ldquoThey were always going to give us a real battle and you canrsquot give the likes of Dearbhla Magee an inch. I just donrsquot understand how she didnrsquot get an All-star nomination. She is one of the best players in Ireland, he continued.ldquoI felt thatwe got in front, we wouldnrsquot concede. Our defence has been immense all year. You can talk all you want about Niamhand the forwards, but the defence was absolutely brilliant.ldquoWe are young and we are hungry and we are going to improve more on the back of what we achieved today.Portaferry: F McGarry, C Coleman, A Mallon, MJ Mageean, C Finnegan, D Coleman, C McKenna, S Sands, N Savage, M Fitzsimons, F Toner, C Coleman, C McConnell, E McGrattan, N Mallon .Subs: G McGrattan for C McConnell , E Gallagher for N Savage , M McNally for M Fitzsimons .Liatroim: N OrsquoToole, Aacute OrsquoToole, K McAleenan, D McCabe, O Brown, K McMullan, A Brown, SL Clarke, D Magee , A McCrickard , A McAleenan , E McAleenan, C Davidson, D Brown, N McKibben.Sub: O Blaney for C Davidson .Referee: Paddy Brannigan..prettyPhoto

title: Schoolchildren take part in Dragons’ Den style debate
story: STUDENTS from six local schools took part in a recent Dragonsrsquo Den-style event in Downpatrick.Down High School hosted the event organised by Newry, Mourne and Down Councilrsquos Womenrsquos Working Group to celebrate Local Democracy Week.Students from Down High were joined by others from St Colmanrsquos High and Sixth Form College in Ballynahinch, St Josephrsquos Crossmaglen, Kilkeelrsquos St Louis, St Markrsquos, Warrenpoint and St Maryrsquos Newry to debate a motion on ldquoprotecting the environment, local communities take action.The Down High team was crowned the winner when students put forward their ideas on organising an eco-fun day and tree planting event for the community to promote and demonstrate the local authorityrsquos commitment to climate change.The winning debating  team included sixth form students Cherith Woods, Anna Shiel, Sara McGeown-Hamilton and Ashia Erskine.They will be invited to attend the local authorityrsquos next monthly meeting at the Downshire Civic Centre in Downpatrick on December  at pm to present their winning motion to councillors and agree a way forward to develop their ideas.Members of the Dragonsrsquo Den judging  included council chairwoman Cathy Mason, a number of local councillors and the local authorityrsquos Director of Corporate Services, Dorinnia Carville.The judges said the motion was very informative and complimented the many initiatives that the local authority is currently involved with.Cllr Mason thanked the students and teachers from each of the six schools for participating in Local Democracy Week event.ldquoOne of the councilrsquos strategic objectives is to empower and improve the capacity of our communities, she explained.ldquoFrom listening to the debates, I have no doubt that each of the students will continue to make an invaluable and positive contribution to our local district, as well as acting as great ambassadors for Newry, Mourne and Down in the future.Cllr Mason wished all the students well in their studies and has no doubt that they have a bright future ahead.She also encourage any of the students who may be interested, to consider becoming a councillor as it is a great way to positively contribute to their community..prettyPhoto

title: Sleeping Beauty pantomime at arts centre
story: A DOWNPATRICK mixed ability drama group is getting ready to go back on the stage in front of a live audience.Dramability will be presenting the pantomime Sleeping Beauty in Down Arts Centre on Saturday and Sunday, December -.It will their first live performance since the lockdown and also the first show at the arts centre since the lockdown.Dramability recently celebrated our th anniversary and there are plans for a special event to mark this occasion in early .The group continued to run throughout the pandemic and produced a number of short videos, including makaton signed songs, and held a virtual Culture Night,an Irish festival of entertainment for St Patrickrsquos Day, a summer festival and interactive scavenger hunts.A spokeswoman for Dramability said: ldquoAlthough our online events and activites were a lot of fun, our members were very isolated and have missed being together.ldquoWe also know that our annual pantomime is the highlight of many peoplersquos Christmas and we were incredibly sad that we couldnrsquot be on stage in December .ldquoWe relaunched our in-person drama classes with a summer scheme this year and have been hard at work on bringing Sleeping Beauty to the stage.The performance on Saturday, December , is at .pm, with the following dayrsquos performance at pm. Tickets cost pound, with a pound concession, and are available from any of Dramability members or via the facebook page, facebook dramability..prettyPhoto

title: TUV selects Cooper for Strangford constituency
story: THE TUV has chosen Stephen Cooper as its Strangford candidate in next yearrsquos Assembly election.The Ards and North Down councillor, who lives in Comber, has served on the local authority for the past seven years.The TUV said Mr Cooper ldquoknows the needs and issues of Strangford at first hand and after over  years of international travel, brings extensive global business experience to accentuate his negotiating abilities which will be crucial in the coming Assembly term to challenge the Northern Ireland Protocol and the many other issues that unionism faces.Having worked in Stormont in the years after the Belfast Agreement for the UK Unionist Party, the TUV says Mr Cooper has ldquoinvaluable political experience as well as his widespread knowledge of the world outside of the political bubble to offer to the electorate.The party says as a former UDR soldier, he is well aware of the ongoing need for robust application of the rule of law and remains determined to continue to vehemently oppose the appeasement of terrorism at all costs.ldquoI am delighted to receive unanimous backing and support from my local branch members and party officers to carry the baton and give the people of Strangford a real alternative, said Mr Cooper following his formal nomination.ldquoHeadlines in the past few days have underscored how Stormont has failed on bread and butter issues like health. Since devolution ed in , the number of hospital beds has reduced by ,.ldquoWe have one of the lowest numbers of ICU beds per , of population in the western world and the NI Executive has failed when it comes to this core issue and many others, impacting the day-to-day lives of countless people across Northern Ireland.Mr Cooper argued that in constitutional terms, ldquothe damage to the Union is at a critical stage.He continued: ldquoThe sea border remains in situ and the High Court has found that Article Six of the Act of Union is no longer in place as a result of the NI Protocol which has been foisted on the people of Northern Ireland at a huge financial cost.ldquoData shows the out-workings of a deliberate strategy to ert trade from within the UK market, and annexe us from the Union Kingdom.Mr Cooper said people across Strangford were ldquoshocked and outraged that not a single MLA from the area voted against bringing in  EU directives and regulations into Northern Ireland.ldquoSuch dereliction of duty is unforgivable and I can assure the people of Strangford thated next year they will find in their TUV MLA a voice of principled and determined opposition to all attempts to undermine our position within the UK. The future of the Union is at stake.TUV leader Jim Allister said he is pleased to commend Mr Cooper to the people of Strangford for the upcoming Assembly election.ldquoStephen is a strong local candidate who I am confident will provide the people of the constituency in which I was educated with first class representation, he said.ldquoThe TUV looks forward to this election with confidence having witnessed a signicant growth in both interest and membership of the party locally. Strangford is very much a TUV target in the upcoming Assembly election and I look forward to Stephen joining me on the Stormont benches..prettyPhoto

title: Virtual reality experience of Ballykinlar WWI hut
story: A NEW virtual reality model experience of the replica First World War Armstrong hut which opened recently at the Down County Museum has been formally launched.The hut mirrors those which had been in place at Ballykinlar camp with the new facility hailed as a major new tourist attraction at the English Street museum in Downpatrick.Initially built to to house , Belfast men training with the thDivision for active service on the Western Front, including at the Battle of the Somme in July , they later housed , republican internees.The men were arrested all over Ireland during the Irish War of Independence in late  and , with the soldiers in  and the internees in  given the same beds, made from three planks, with four army blankets to sleep on.The original ft by ft timber huts, clad with corrugated iron, housed evacuees from Malta, American GIs and German prisoners of war during World War Two and also sheltered Hungarian refugees after the Russian invasion in . The last huts were dismantled in .The new virtual reality K model experience was developed by the Centre for Data Digitation and Analysis at Belfastrsquos Queenrsquos University and showcases historical research, key interviews with project contributors and also offers insights into the hutrsquos erse and shared history.The recreated Ballykinlar History Hut, complete with tunnel entrance, was constructed and fitted out during the coronavirus lockdown as part of Newry, Mourne and Down Councilrsquos lsquoshared history and culturersquo programme, which was supported by the EU rsquos PEACE IV Programme managed by the Special EU Programmes Body.The immersive nature of virtual reality has allowed the content creators at Queenrsquos to explore and develop innovative ways of learning and teaching ideas through interactive means.Residents and viewers of the new virtual experience will gain a  degree, D view inside the hut and it will enable people from around the world to tap into this rich historical resource from their mobile, PC or laptop, with or without the use of virtual reality headsets.Council chairwoman Cathy Mason,said the virtual reality walkthrough experience added a ldquovaluable digital element to the Ballykinlar History Hut.ldquoIt is possible to move around the hut and look at everything inside it thanks to the detailed scans made by the Centre for Data Digitisation and Analysis at Queenrsquos. It is now possible to spend hours exploring it from anywhere in the world, she added.The innovative project will allow the museum to offer a virtual tour of the hut and share this historic exhibition worldwide.Council officials say the new experience will provide viewers with a self-guided exploration through a private viewing, enabling them to watch videos and access the stories of those who occupied the huts at Ballykinlar between  and .They say access to the hutrsquos extensive artefacts and history becomes both immediate and more accessible regardless of the viewerrsquos location.To access the Ballykinlar History Hut VR Experience visit https:my.matterport show  mJRDDufRY while further information is also available at www.facebook BallykinlarHistoryHut..prettyPhoto

title: avian influenza housing order come force
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % lessThose ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local servicesThese adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityNew housing measures are to be introduced as part of the Avian Influenza Prevention Zone in Northern Irelandfrom November , Agriculture Minister Edwin Poots has announced.The decision to introduce a housing order follows the confirmation of  cases of Highly-Pathogenic Avian InfluenzaHN across Great Britain and one case in a commercial turkey flock in Co. Monaghan.DAERA officials have also confirmed, late last night, the presence of Avian Influenza in two wild birds retrieved from the Belfast Waterworks site earlier this week.Disease control zones have been put in place around all infected premises to mitigate against onward disease spread.Under the new housing measures, all bird keepers in NI will be legally required to keep their birds indoors or otherwise separate from wild birds, and to follow strict biosecurity measures.This applies to owners of pet birds, commercial flocks or just a few birds in a backyard or hobby flock.Announcing the decision to introduce a housing order, Minister Poots said: ldquoI took the decision to introduce the new housing measures in order to try to prevent an incursion of avian influenza into the poultry flock in Northern Ireland.ldquoIt is now a legal requirement for all poultry and captive bird keepers to keep their birds housed or otherwise separate from wild birds.ldquoThis decision was based on sound expert advice and in consultation with industry.ldquoThis decision to house is an additional step to the Avian Influenza Prevention Zoneintroduced on November , and is another necessary precautionary measure requiring all bird keepers to keep their birds housed.ldquoThese housing measures build on the strengthened biosecurity measures that were brought in as part of the AIPZ.ldquoSince my decision to introduce the housing order, we have now discovered avian flu in two wild birds in Belfast ndash that tells us unequivocally that the disease is already here and in our wild bird population.ldquoKeeping it out of the commercial flocks is now down to our poultry sector and the measures they take to keep the disease out.ldquoAdhering to, and a constant review of, all biosecurity measures is the best weapon we have to avoid an incursion.ldquoMy officials will continue to liaise closely with stakeholders and colleagues in GB and the Republic as the situation develops.To assist all bird keepers in complying with the new rules, a Biosecurity self-assessment tool has been developed that is available on the DAERA website.If avian influenza were to enter NI, the disease would have a signicant and devastating impact on our poultry industry, international trade and the wider economy.Poultry and captive bird keepers are advised to be vigilant for any signs of disease in their birds and any wild birds, and to seek prompt advice from their vetthey have any concerns.This website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards
